body:
### busy status indicator for  buffers in statusline

Adds new buffer specific boolean option 'busy'.
When busy is set it indicates the buffer is busy. For now this busy status is shown in the default statusline as `<busy>`

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1eeb6a81-ef20-4c73-9f6c-e6dae694b2a2)

related  #32084

comment_regular_data.body:
Update: this should be a number instead of a boolean. So plugins, and our ["progress" interface](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32537) can increment/decrement the per-buffer "busy state" without stepping on each other.

Edit: I'm waffling on this, because there are still obvious edge cases where the number may be over-decremented, etc. But I guess plugins could just treat it as boolean if they want.

> Update: this should be a number instead of a boolean. So plugins, and our ["progress" interface](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32537) can increment/decrement the per-buffer "busy state" without stepping on each other.

Should I show the number in default statusline? or just the symbol as long as it's above 0? There isn't an atomic increment or decrement on options, right? Also, do we care about that?

Also, if we make it increment-decrement based, is a race condition possible?

> or just the symbol as long as it's above 0?

let's do that for now.

> There isn't an atomic increment or decrement on options, right?

vimscript/lua execution is single-threaded so is inherently atomic.

I got curious to see how concise it would be to implement busy spinner in default statusline while allowing to set the spinner parameters.

To make things easier, I used similar "start spinner if the value of some numerical buffer option is bigger than a threshold" (I used 'shiftwidth'). Here is what I ended up with (which I don't think is *that* bad to be put in '_defaults.lua'):

```lua
-- A global value only for prototype. In the final result will be `local`
-- with potential to be computed from something like a 'spinner' option.
_G.spinner_steps = {
  { '⠋', 100 },
  { '⠙', 100 },
  { '⠹', 100 },
  { '⠸', 100 },
  { '⠼', 100 },
  { '⠴', 100 },
  { '⠦', 100 },
  { '⠧', 100 },
  { '⠇', 100 },
  { '⠏', 100 },
}

local spinner_timers = {}

local start_spinner = function(bufnr)
  if spinner_timers[bufnr] then return end
  local timer = vim.uv.new_timer()
  local steps = vim.deepcopy(_G.spinner_steps)
  local i, n = 0, #steps
  local advance = function()
    i = i % n + 1
    local text, delay = unpack(steps[i])

    vim.b[bufnr]._busy_spinner = text
    vim.api.nvim__redraw({ statusline = true })

    timer:set_repeat(delay)
    timer:again()
  end

  timer:start(0, 0, vim.schedule_wrap(advance))
  spinner_timers[bufnr] = timer
end

local stop_spinner = function(bufnr)
  if not spinner_timers[bufnr] then return end

  vim.b[bufnr]._busy_spinner = nil
  vim.api.nvim__redraw({ statusline = true })

  spinner_timers[bufnr]:stop()
  spinner_timers[bufnr]:close()
  spinner_timers[bufnr] = nil
end

local show_spinner = function()
  local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
  if vim.bo[bufnr].shiftwidth >= 4 then
    start_spinner(bufnr)
  else
    stop_spinner(bufnr)
  end
end

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('OptionSet', { pattern = 'shiftwidth', callback = show_spinner })

-- Set prototype "default" statusline
vim.o.statusline = 'Buffer %n %{getbufvar("%", "_busy_spinner", "")}'
```

Here is a demo of the spinner with "linear" easing (i.e. constant delay) and "quadratic" easing (i.e. delays change linearly):

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/399b5390-0cd0-4921-a21c-eb7d477055e0
